description:
Lottia gigantea, commonly known as the owl limpet, is a species of large marine gastropod mollusk in the family Lottiidae. It is native to the Pacific coast of North America, ranging from Baja California, Mexico, to Oregon, United States.

The owl limpet is a keystone species in the rocky intertidal ecosystems it inhabits, playing a crucial role in the community structure and dynamics. It is a grazing herbivore, feeding primarily on microalgae and macroalgae, and can significantly impact the diversity and abundance of other organisms through its feeding activities.

The shell of the owl limpet is large, conical, and typically measures up to 10 centimeters in diameter. The shell is gray, brown, or black in color and has a distinctive radial pattern of ridges and grooves. The animal's foot is muscular, allowing it to firmly adhere to the rocky substrate, and it can move slowly by gliding along the surface.

Owl limpets are long-lived, with some individuals reaching ages of 20 years or more. They exhibit a complex life cycle, with both sexual and asexual reproductive strategies. The species is considered to be an indicator of the overall health and ecological integrity of the rocky intertidal ecosystems it inhabits.
